body: FYI: We use RAT in Apache Cordova release automation tools https://github.com/apache/cordova-coho/blob/master/src/audit-license-headers.js
rebase and merged 4a2b2455ddb144fd3ff921dd2d78146ccae7acf3
@rabbah  ah so your saying that the REST API already support a `sort` parameter that CLI can pass to it to sort by date or alphabetically?

I tried `wsk list` and `wsk rule get` with `-v` and was not able to see a date property in the return data. I was just trying to understand where is this sorting that your proposing happens client or server side.

@dubeejw thanks for the doc update Woot!
rebase and merged 189968b19df1eceb66823397ceb0db03bafdd791
No I'm saying records in the database have a date field. It is not visible to you as the end user.

OK How are you proposing we implement this sorting featured flag?

It looks like it can't be done ONLY with CLI changes.

Something along the lines to add support in the backend to provide a parameter that get's used to return the sorted list, or return the list with the date information for the client to do the sorting.
We already have sort by date. This is the current ordering. I'm simply proposing that you choose a default (name vs date) and guard the sort in the cli by such a flag.

Ah see, make sense now. I think it's being a long day for me ðŸ¤£  going home now.

@lzbj I assume you understood the propose change, very simple to handle. 

I propose flag name `sort` possible values `date` or `name` 

My OCD tells me that default when flag not specify should be `name`
But practical person says `date`

I'm OK flipping a coin, or if someone has a strong opinion
I'm referencing the other PR #1715 which solves the problem with invoking actions without having to provide whisk credentials in case someone else stumbles about the same problem I did.

Thought: sort by name by default and add `-t` to sort by time (matching `ls -t` for example).
For activations however should we support sorting lexically? One thought is to sort lexically by the corresponding action/trigger/rule name and within each group sort by time. And the flag `-t` could then flatten the grouping... Seems confusing though.
@rabbah ,@csantanapr, I'll try to figure out and and a flag. Thanks for review.
@mdeuser if the string is truncated, how can someone find out of full name of the action being used?
@mbehrendt - the entire API, including the actionName and actionNamespace, can be obtained (in swagger format) via the `wsk api-experimental get` command.
@mdeuser i think my question is ....how do i know which parameter to pass to `wsk api-experimental get` , if i can see the full string in `wsk api-experimental list` ?

Some high-level comments from a first, superficial, pass:

* `"export": true` is a very generic-sounding annotation. Maybe `web_export`? (do we CamelCase?)
* I'm a concerned with the monumental work that comes with trying to encode an HTTP request into JSON fields (passed to the action), and interpreting a JSON object as an HTTP response. I'm afraid that conventions can only ever get us the easy cases, and that soon enough we'll be maintaining and documenting dozens of them. Could we instead resort to some externally documented schema? E.g. HAR has subsections for [requests](http://www.softwareishard.com/blog/har-12-spec/#request) and [responses](http://www.softwareishard.com/blog/har-12-spec/#response), but there may also be other suitable formats. Within actions, I'd expect that we will rapidly support translating these encoded objects into user-friendly libraries (e.g. `request`).
* With the comment above in mind, I would be in favor of simplifying the implementation and removing path projection (the path would be one of the components passed to the action, which can decide how to handle it).

It's fair to change the annotation. When this is moved out of experimental the annotation should then be promoted to a first class property which might require a schema change.

Note that the http bits were the last commit when I opened the PR (it wasn't immediately my intention to do it). Much of the work in place is to enable the web based activation. For that and for making standard actions accessible without buying into http request/response, the projection is still useful. That said as you noticed the action does receive the unmatched parts and can decide how to respond anyway. This I posit makes for a gentler migration for actions. For moving express apps the counter is likely true and your points are well taken. 

For the http bits what I supported is header setting and nothing else. This was motivated by a use case around oauth flow where having redirects is helpful.

Your suggestion of not reinventing the wheel and using some accepted schema based approach is all goodness. I'm for it.

@mbehrendt - if i understand your question correctly, the command `wsk api-experimental get BASEPATH` will retrieve the entire API definition with all of the API's action names listed.

let's discuss the `api-experimental list` output.  unlimited column sizes are possible, but at the risk of overflowing the terminal row.  some possible options
- unlimited column size
- set an appropriate maximum column size that's expected to cover the large majority of use cases.  use `get` as a backup
- add an option to the command to display the list in such that the columns are vertical instead of horizontal
why isn't the variable length content at the end of the table that way you can take up as much space as you need? so what if you overflow the terminal window. Inspiration: `ls`.

there are actual 3 columns that have variable length values - the action name, the basepath/apiname, and the full API url (that contains the basepath and relative path)
```
ok: APIs
Action                    Verb  API Name  URL
/myaction/whisk.system  delete       /bp  http://172.17.0.1:9001/api/51a0ad05-91ce-491e-9427-bedad3698e00/bp/rp
```

So how about a different layout then?
```
/myaction/whisk.system
Verb:  		delete       
API Name: 	/bp  
URL:		http://172.17.0.1:9001/api/51a0ad05-91ce-491e-9427-bedad3698e00/bp/rp

```
Yeah.. that's was the third bullet option - switch the columns from running across the horizontal to run across the vertical... perhaps controlled/enabled by a CLI option

Ok, got it.

## Changes to be applied for "Docker for Mac"

### 1. ip address for local environment
In OSX environment, there is no docker network(172.17.0.0/32).

**Options**
1. In the document, guide user to manually change the ip address in ```ansible/environment/local/hosts```
2. Properly update the default IP
   (But I doubt there exists all-round default ip for mac and linux.)

### 2. Enabling Docker remote API
Docker remote API is not enabled by default in Docker for Mac.

**Options**
1. In the document, guide user to manually run socat container or do other workaround.
2. Create the ansible step for this issue.

I am inclined to make just guide for this issue.
There could be many workaround for this.
I think it will be better to give users a choice. 

### ETC

If there is no reason not to add apigateway.yml in the guide, I will include this step in the guide.(including existing guides)

One more question is, currently, ```wsklogs``` directory is created with root ownership.
Even though all files in each sub directory are create with current user ownership.

Is there any reason it should have root ownership?

i like the approach of offered a switch on the cli to enable it. i think the default should be the 'everything-in-one-row' view, due to better / more compact readability , while the alternative view can be used as a fallback on case of very long strings

It seems someone already encounter the same issue,
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/22343083/json-marshaling-with-long-numbers-in-golang-gives-floating-point-number

So we add a flag to let user choose?  or By default use decoder as numbers? Any ideas?
would it be possible to just treat everything as a string? any major downsides to that?

Decode it as float64 as current, we can change the code to use string representation, just FYR @mbehrendt .

Closing, superseded by #1735
+1 to making the storage implementation pluggable. In addition to the examples above: an in-memory implementation would be cool for (unit/integration-) tests or dev setups.

I have an intial prototype here for an in memory store to accelerate testing: https://github.com/rabbah/openwhisk/blob/object-access/tests/src/whisk/core/database/test/MockDocumentFactory.scala.

Replacing couchdb with another nosql db is likely easier than a sql db. You can see from the "mock" db, there is a generic interface to implement by other datastores.

This topic came up again on the ASF OW [list](https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/775b91a88cc23b568511ab1428143c0f28abb3b86fa03e6d0dd17870@%3Cdev.openwhisk.apache.org%3E). Bringing the discussion back to this issue. In particular, I have a related use case and a question to this discussion:

**Use case**
We would like to set immutable parameters that each action in a sequence can read (set per invocation). The background is (copying from the [list](https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/597f4c4929d56b2124cc2674902e7c854ce7880bd4bfdc058164d590@%3Cdev.openwhisk.apache.org%3E)):

> * assume OW deployments where an API gateway authenticates incoming requests and sets e.g. the userId as a header that gets forwarded to the action
> * the subsequently invoked actionâ€™s code wants to read that header (userId)
> * if a sequence was invoked by the request each action in the sequence must be able to read that header (and be sure that it has not been tampered with by previous actions in the sequence)

**Question**
IIUC the discussion above has found consensus on this [proposal](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/116#issuecomment-229976950).
I wonder why the parameter *values* are show up in the sequence definition at *creation* time of the sequence in

> â€œwsk action create sequence S â€”action A1 P11 V11 P12 V12 â€”action A2 P21 V21 P22 V23"

That seems to not allow for setting parameter values at invocation time - or do I misinterpret the proposal?

FYI.  While not the fix for this issue.. if a unsupported/invalid API verb is provided, the error message will provide the list of supported verbs
```
error: Unable to parse api command arguments: 'badverb' is not a valid API verb.  Valid values are: [GET PUT POST DELETE PATCH HEAD OPTIONS]
```

Some example output.  The option flag label is up for discussion.  In this example, the flag label includes the word `rotate` since that is spreadsheet/image parlance for transposing the columns from horizontal/landscape orientation to vertical/portrait.
```
$ wsk -i api-experimental create /my/basepath/is/quite/long /and/so/is/my/path delete mylongpkgname/mylongactionname -n "And the API Name is also quite long"
ok: created API /my/basepath/is/quite/long/and/so/is/my/path DELETE for action /_/mylongpkgname/mylongactionname
http://172.17.0.1:9001/api/15c54aa3-6a07-4a78-9c4e-a70f73e73b93/my/basepath/is/quite/long/and/so/is/my/path
$ wsk -i api-experimental list
ok: APIs
Action                                      Verb                        API Name  URL
/whisk.system/mylongpkgname/mylongaction  delete  And the API Name is also quite  http://172.17.0.1:9001/api/15c54aa3-6a07-4a78-9c4e-a70f73e73b93/my/basepath/is/quite/long/and/so/is/my/path
$ wsk -i api-experimental list --rotate-output
ok: APIs
Action: /whisk.system/mylongpkgname/mylongactionname
  Verb: delete
  API Name: And the API Name is also quite long
  URL: http://172.17.0.1:9001/api/15c54aa3-6a07-4a78-9c4e-a70f73e73b93/my/basepath/is/quite/long/and/so/is/my/path
```

@psuter can you summarize your findings for future investigators?

In memory is cool and a good excuse to implement plugable storage, but real persistence will be required between starts and stops of Whisk server. And we only have Couch and Cloudant now. So it doesn't address my need.

What are the JSON/nosql database options available right now that are not servers (daemons) but a plain library that accesses its files? This would be the way to go. This is also the architecture for SQLite (which I find very elegant for small environments).

In my personal opinion, current architecture (obligation of a separate database just for configs) might find adoption resistance, specially for private deployments. Couch is not very popular amongst sysadmins (the guys that will handle the environment)

See the tests here: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1744/files
Feel free to cherry pick and then close my pr.

I never really super fan this `eval` hackery it feels like magic.

I proposed we look into writing the file int tmpfs (i.e. memory) and then do a clean `require("./tmpfs/action.js")` 

I think it's important to fix this, as I can see a lot people using `let` or `const` and maybe other context related problems.

We would need to tell folks to make a migration some how that user will need to `export.main = main`

OR we could try to eval, catch the exception, and then do the `require` procedure, for a period to allow for migration.
We could also try to append `export.main = main` at the end of the file

Cross linking for future reference https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1032. Partly related.

I could address the first issue with regard to ip address.

The workaround is as follow.

I added alias for loopback interface.
```
sudo ifconfig lo0 alias 172.17.0.1/24
```

And it magically works as expected : )


In details, basically 172.17.0.1(gateway) is osx host machine in container side.
So all the network traffic will be forwarded to host machine via 172.17.0.1 as a gateway.
And it will go out further to the internet via hosts` physical network interface.

The problem was host did not recognize 172.17.0.1 as its local network ip.
If container is trying to connect to other container via 172.17.0.1, host does not accept this request and all the containers are not reachable to each other.

So I added 172.17.0.1 as alias for loopback address and finally it works.
Now we can seamlessly deploy openwhisk with current local inventory file in Docker for Mac environment also. 

You can refer to this issue: https://github.com/docker/docker/issues/22753

I confirmed the DB (CouchDB) stores action codes with non-English data correctly by reviewing the CouchDB web interface for my vagrant install. 

http://172.17.0.1:5984/_utils/database.html?vagrant_vagrant-ubuntu-trusty-64_whisks
(Overview > vagrant_vagrant-ubuntu-trusty-64_whisks > guest/_myaction_)

This may mean wrong charset conversion happens when loading action codes or producing a response in the Invoker.

> Why is this needed now? Is it compatible with cloudant?

Needed to successfully operate OpenWhisk :). Yes its fully compatible with either CouchDB or Cloudant.

> Why is the pip install of couchdb needed?

It's needed to be able to run the script (it depends on the couchdb client).

I suspect that OpenWhisk is using the wrong codepage when actions are being executed. My guess is that they are using ISO8859-1 (Latin 1) when they should be using UTF-8 (Unicode). This should be a simple configuration change and would enable them to avoid having to do a conversion as the actions and data are most likely in UTF-8 already.
